subject: Re: [junit] Re: Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: ... Understood. Maybe your client would prefer some expert help for a day or two? Even a half-day remote consultation would jump-start you. E-mail me directly
messageBody:
Tracey Annison wrote:

> Thanks for even trying. :) I just don't know how to explain it better
> without posting all the code for a "chunk", but a) you REALLY don't
> want to wade through all that, and b) I'm not sure the client would
> like it!

Understood. Maybe your client would prefer some expert help for a day or
two? Even a half-day remote consultation would jump-start you. E-mail me
directly if that's remotely feasible.

> But I reckon you've got it there. We can & do JUnit it all, but it's
> just such a big job to do. You're right that I can't, say, test
> anything about one Domain object without JMocking it's DAO and half a
> dozen more to make it with, and setting up their stubs & expects & so
> on.
> But maybe that's normal?

It's normal to need to mock/stub collaborators. It's enough normal to
have a lot of them, but there are definite antipatterns, such as this
common gem:

I mock this collaborator to return that object, which I then have
to mock, which has to return another object, which I then have to mock...

You get the picture. I imagine this antipattern is at the heart of much
of your problem. There is probably some inappropriate layering going on.
I'd need to dive headlong into code to be certain, but I could probably
tell you in 30 minutes if you led me through it.

> Cheers for the pointers to those books - I believe Da Boss is looking
> for some reading recommendations for us, so that's perfect!

I hope they help.

Take care.
